Creational patterns.name: Abstract factory
Creational patterns.description: Provide an interface for creating families of related or dependent objects without specifying their concrete classes.

Creational patterns.name: Builder
Creational patterns.description: Separate the construction of a complex object from its representation, allowing the same construction process to create various representations.

Creational patterns.name: Dependency injection
Creational patterns.description: A class accepts the objects it requires from an injector instead of creating the objects directly.

Creational patterns.name: Factory method
Creational patterns.description: Define an interface for creating a single object, but let subclasses decide which class to instantiate. Factory Method lets a class defer instantiation to subclasses.

Creational patterns.name: Lazy initialization
Creational patterns.description: Tactic of delaying the creation of an object, the calculation of a value, or some other expensive process until the first time it is needed. This pattern appears in the GoF catalog as "virtual proxy", an implementation strategy for the Proxy pattern.

Creational patterns.name: Multiton
Creational patterns.description: Ensure a class has only named instances, and provide a global point of access to them.

Creational patterns.name: Object pool
Creational patterns.description: Avoid expensive acquisition and release of resources by recycling objects that are no longer in use. Can be considered a generalisation of connection pool and thread pool patterns.

Creational patterns.name: Prototype
Creational patterns.description: Specify the kinds of objects to create using a prototypical instance, and create new objects from the 'skeleton' of an existing object, thus boosting performance and keeping memory footprints to a minimum.

Creational patterns.name: Resource acquisition is initialization (RAII)
Creational patterns.description: Ensure that resources are properly released by tying them to the lifespan of suitable objects.

Creational patterns.name: Singleton
Creational patterns.description: Ensure a class has only one instance, and provide a global point of access to it.

Structural patterns.name: Adapter, Wrapper, or Translator
Structural patterns.description: Convert the interface of a class into another interface clients expect. An adapter lets classes work together that could not otherwise because of incompatible interfaces. The enterprise integration pattern equivalent is the translator.

Structural patterns.name: Bridge
Structural patterns.description: Decouple an abstraction from its implementation allowing the two to vary independently.

Structural patterns.name: Composite
Structural patterns.description: Compose objects into tree structures to represent part-whole hierarchies. Composite lets clients treat individual objects and compositions of objects uniformly.

Structural patterns.name: Decorator
Structural patterns.description: Attach additional responsibilities to an object dynamically keeping the same interface. Decorators provide a flexible alternative to subclassing for extending functionality.

Structural patterns.name: Extension object
Structural patterns.description: Adding functionality to a hierarchy without changing the hierarchy.
other: Agile Software Development, Principles, Patterns, and Practices

Structural patterns.name: Facade
Structural patterns.description: Provide a unified interface to a set of interfaces in a subsystem. Facade defines a higher-level interface that makes the subsystem easier to use.

Structural patterns.name: Flyweight
Structural patterns.description: Use sharing to support large numbers of similar objects efficiently.

Structural patterns.name: Front controller
Structural patterns.description: The pattern relates to the design of Web applications. It provides a centralized entry point for handling requests.

Structural patterns.name: Marker
Structural patterns.description: Empty interface to associate metadata with a class.

Structural patterns.name: Module
Structural patterns.description: Group several related elements, such as classes, singletons, methods, globally used, into a single conceptual entity.

Structural patterns.name: Proxy
Structural patterns.description: Provide a surrogate or placeholder for another object to control access to it.

Structural patterns.name: Twin
Structural patterns.description: Twin allows modeling of multiple inheritance in programming languages that do not support this feature.

Behavioral patterns.name: Blackboard
Behavioral patterns.description: Artificial intelligence pattern for combining disparate sources of data (see blackboard system)

Behavioral patterns.name: Chain of responsibility
Behavioral patterns.description: Avoid coupling the sender of a request to its receiver by giving more than one object a chance to handle the request. Chain the receiving objects and pass the request along the chain until an object handles it.

Behavioral patterns.name: Command
Behavioral patterns.description: Encapsulate a request as an object, thereby allowing for the parameterization of clients with different requests, and the queuing or logging of requests. It also allows for the support of undoable operations.

Behavioral patterns.name: Interpreter
Behavioral patterns.description: Given a language, define a representation for its grammar along with an interpreter that uses the representation to interpret sentences in the language.

Behavioral patterns.name: Iterator
Behavioral patterns.description: Provide a way to access the elements of an aggregate object sequentially without exposing its underlying representation.

Behavioral patterns.name: Mediator
Behavioral patterns.description: Define an object that encapsulates how a set of objects interact. Mediator promotes loose coupling by keeping objects from referring to each other explicitly, and it allows their interaction to vary independently.

Behavioral patterns.name: Memento
Behavioral patterns.description: Without violating encapsulation, capture and externalize an object's internal state allowing the object to be restored to this state later.

Behavioral patterns.name: Null object
Behavioral patterns.description: Avoid null references by providing a default object.

Behavioral patterns.name: Observer or Publish/subscribe
Behavioral patterns.description: Define a one-to-many dependency between objects where a state change in one object results in all its dependents being notified and updated automatically.

Behavioral patterns.name: Servant
Behavioral patterns.description: Define common functionality for a group of classes.

Behavioral patterns.name: Specification
Behavioral patterns.description: Recombinable business logic in a Boolean fashion.

Behavioral patterns.name: State
Behavioral patterns.description: Allow an object to alter its behavior when its internal state changes. The object will appear to change its class.

Behavioral patterns.name: Strategy
Behavioral patterns.description: Define a family of algorithms, encapsulate each one, and make them interchangeable. Strategy lets the algorithm vary independently from clients that use it.

Behavioral patterns.name: Template method
Behavioral patterns.description: Define the skeleton of an algorithm in an operation, deferring some steps to subclasses. Template method lets subclasses redefine certain steps of an algorithm without changing the algorithm's structure.

Behavioral patterns.name: Visitor
Behavioral patterns.description: Represent an operation to be performed on the elements of an object structure. Visitor lets a new operation be defined without changing the classes of the elements on which it operates.

Concurrency patterns.name: Active Object
Concurrency patterns.description: Decouples method execution from method invocation that reside in their own thread of control. The goal is to introduce concurrency, by using asynchronous method invocation and a scheduler for handling requests.

Concurrency patterns.name: Balking
Concurrency patterns.description: Only execute an action on an object when the object is in a particular state.

Concurrency patterns.name: Binding properties
Concurrency patterns.description: Combining multiple observers to force properties in different objects to be synchronized or coordinated in some way.

Concurrency patterns.name: Blockchain
Concurrency patterns.description: Decentralized way to store data and agree on ways of processing it in a Merkle tree, optionally using digital signature for any individual contributions.

Concurrency patterns.name: Compute kernel
Concurrency patterns.description: The same calculation many times in parallel, differing by integer parameters used with non-branching pointer math into shared arrays, such as GPU-optimized Matrix multiplication or Convolutional neural network.

Concurrency patterns.name: Double-checked locking
Concurrency patterns.description: Reduce the overhead of acquiring a lock by first testing the locking criterion (the 'lock hint') in an unsafe manner; only if that succeeds does the actual locking logic proceed. Can be unsafe when implemented in some language/hardware combinations. It can therefore sometimes be considered an anti-pattern.

Concurrency patterns.name: Event-based asynchronous
Concurrency patterns.description: Addresses problems with the asynchronous pattern that occur in multithreaded programs.

Concurrency patterns.name: Guarded suspension
Concurrency patterns.description: Manages operations that require both a lock to be acquired and a precondition to be satisfied before the operation can be executed.

Concurrency patterns.name: Join
Concurrency patterns.description: Join-pattern provides a way to write concurrent, parallel and distributed programs by message passing. Compared to the use of threads and locks, this is a high-level programming model.

Concurrency patterns.name: Lock
Concurrency patterns.description: One thread puts a "lock" on a resource, preventing other threads from accessing or modifying it.

Concurrency patterns.name: Messaging design pattern (MDP)
Concurrency patterns.description: Allows the interchange of information (i.e. messages) between components and applications.

Concurrency patterns.name: Monitor object
Concurrency patterns.description: An object whose methods are subject to mutual exclusion, thus preventing multiple objects from erroneously trying to use it at the same time.

Concurrency patterns.name: Reactor
Concurrency patterns.description: A reactor object provides an asynchronous interface to resources that must be handled synchronously.

Concurrency patterns.name: Read-write lock
Concurrency patterns.description: Allows concurrent read access to an object, but requires exclusive access for write operations.

Concurrency patterns.name: Scheduler
Concurrency patterns.description: Explicitly control when threads may execute single-threaded code.

Concurrency patterns.name: Thread pool
Concurrency patterns.description: A number of threads are created to perform a number of tasks, which are usually organized in a queue. Typically, there are many more tasks than threads. Can be considered a special case of the object pool pattern.

Concurrency patterns.name: Thread-specific storage
Concurrency patterns.description: Static or "global" memory local to a thread.
